name: geo-localization-project
title: Deep Learning For GeoLocating Street Level Imagery
subtitle: 2024-2025 Master's Project

items.text: It turns out that there's enough pre-trained models floating around that we can skip to the fun stuff. This project creates a pseudo-ensemble of Machine Learning Models for GeoLocalization of street-level imagery at the multi-neighborhood scale.

Existing models focus on broader scales. This pseudo-ensemble of models 'slots in' as a final step in a broader GeoLocalization pipeline. We analyze text, objects, and color space (using a bunch of conveniently great pre-existing models) to generate intermediary embeddings and train our model(s) therein.

The methodology involves extracting and analyzing GeoInformative Features using fine-tuned object detection models to identify geographic indicators, such as signage, crosswalks, and architectural elements.

Optical Character Recognition (OCR) is used to extract text, which is then transformed into higher-dimensional embeddings using a pre-trained text embedding model. Color distributions, indicative of geographic location, are captured using HSV histogram embeddings.
Three machine learning models are employed to geolocate an unseen image: K-means clustering, a CNN with Attention, and a Multi-Dense Network with Attention.
From a dataset of 150,510 images, we achieved an accuracy of 1.3km (approx) for a 20kmÂ² candidate area. The overall project was graded as an A through the University of Canterbury.
As AI continues to evolve, it is essential to address the ethical implications of its use. Issues such as data privacy, bias in algorithms, and job displacement need to be carefully managed.

name: ai-climate-modeling
title: AI-Powered Climate Modeling
subtitle: Using Machine Learning to Predict Climate Change Trends

items.text: Climate change is one of the biggest challenges of our time. With the increasing availability of environmental data, AI-driven models can help us predict temperature shifts, extreme weather patterns, and long-term climate trends.
We utilize recurrent neural networks (RNNs) and convolutional neural networks (CNNs) trained on satellite imagery and historical weather data to forecast future climate conditions with high accuracy.
Our approach also integrates transfer learning from existing climate simulation models, improving predictions for specific regions vulnerable to climate change.
Using this AI-driven model, we achieved a **92% accuracy** in predicting heatwave occurrences and a **78% accuracy** in long-term precipitation trends.
While AI in climate science is powerful, it also raises concerns about bias in datasets, computational energy usage, and the ethical responsibility of AI-generated predictions.
